question: 1) What is a primary advantage of using MNW over WEL in groundwater modeling? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Yes — MNW captures realistic well behavior including layered flow, head losses, and control limits.

question: 2) Which factors influence the aquifer-to-well conductance (CWC) in a Multi-Node Well? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Conductance depends on geometric and hydraulic properties around the well.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. CWC reflects subsurface and borehole properties, not unrelated boundary elevations.

question: 3) What happens to the Q–h behavior of an MNW when a restart threshold (Qmx) is defined? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Qmx ensures that pumping only restarts when sufficient head is restored and a minimum calculated Q is met.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Qmx defines restart behavior — it does not allow flow to increase while the well is active, and it does not create a visible step in the Q–h curve.

question: 4) In MODFLOW, what conditions may cause a MNW to stop pumping due to head constraints? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Spot on. MNW may stop pumping when physical or hydraulic head constraints are violated.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Well shutdown is related to local head conditions and the minimum flux limit, not Qmx or recharge rates.

question: 5) How is the well skin incorporated in MNW behavior? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Well skin increases resistance and contributes to head loss.
error: ❌ Some of your choices are not correct. Skin increases drawdown — it does not increase conductance nor affect recharge.

question: 6) How can Q–h plots assist in interpreting MNW model behavior? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well done. Q–h plots help understand how pumping responds to drawdown, thresholds, and constraints.
